message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Political Polarization on the Digital Sphere: A Cross-platform, Over-time Analysis of Interactional, Positional, and Affective Polarization on Social Media
Paper Abstract: Political polarization on the digital sphere poses a real challenge to many democracies around the world. Although the issue has received some scholarly attention, there is a need to improve the conceptual precision in the increasingly blurry debate. The use of computational communication science approaches allows us to track political conversations in a fine-grained manner within their natural settings – the realm of interactive social media. The present study combines different algorithmic approaches to studying social media data in order to capture both the interactional structure and content of dynamic political talk online. We conducted an analysis of political polarization across social media platforms (analyzing Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp) over 16 months, with close to a quarter million online contributions regarding a political controversy in Israel. Our comprehensive measurement of interactive political talk enables us to address three key aspects of political polarization: (1) interactional polarization – homophilic versus heterophilic user interactions; (2) positional polarization – the positions expressed, and (3) affective polarization – the emotions and attitudes expressed. Our findings indicate that political polarization on social media cannot be conceptualized as a unified phenomenon, as there are significant cross-platform differences. While interactions on Twitter largely conform to established expectations (homophilic interaction patterns, aggravating positional polarization, pronounced inter-group hostility), on WhatsApp, de-polarization occurred over time. Surprisingly, Facebook was found to be the least homophilic platform in terms of interactions, positions, and emotions expressed. Our analysis points to key conceptual distinctions and raises important questions about the drivers and dynamics of political polarization online.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance

Here are the search results for "Social media":

## Definition and Overview

Social media are new media technologies that facilitate the creation, sharing and aggregation of content (such as ideas, interests, and other forms of expression) amongst virtual communities and networks.(no content)These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.

## Uses and Functions

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn. They may be used to promote people, companies, products, and ideas. Social media can be used to consume, publish, or share news.

## Major Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.

## Usage Statistics

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

## Comparison to Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Concerns

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

Here's information about WhatsApp messaging based on the search results:

## Overview

WhatsApp (officially WhatsApp Messenger), owned by Meta Platforms, is an American social media, instant messaging (IM), and Voice over IP (VoIP) service accessible via desktop and mobile app.

## Features

It allows users to send text messages, voice messages, and video messages, make voice and video calls, and share images, documents, user locations, and other content.

## User Base

As of May 2025, the service had 3 billion monthly active users, making it the most used messenger app.

## History

WhatsApp was launched in May 2009.(no content)WhatsApp was founded by Brian Acton and Jan Koum, former employees of Yahoo! Koum incorporated WhatsApp Inc. in California on February 24, 2009.(no content)The service was created by WhatsApp Inc. of Mountain View, California, which was acquired by Facebook in February 2014 for approximately US$19.3 billion.

## Business Version

In January 2018, WhatsApp released a standalone business app called WhatsApp Business which can communicate with the standard WhatsApp client.

## Security

As of 2025, messaging apps like Signal and WhatsApp are designed to exclusively use end-to-end encryption. Both Signal and WhatsApp use the Signal Protocol.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Facebook:

## Overview

Facebook is an American social media and social networking service owned by the American technology conglomerate Meta.

## History and Founding

Facebook was created in 2004 by Mark Zuckerberg with four other Harvard College students and roommates, Eduardo Saverin, Andrew McCollum, Dustin Moskovitz, and Chris Hughes.(no content)It was launched as TheFacebook in 2004 and renamed Facebook in 2005, initially limited to Harvard students before expanding to other colleges and eventually to everyone with a valid email address by 2006.

## Growth and Dominance

Facebook had surpassed MySpace in global traffic and became the world's most popular social media platform.(no content)Facebook introduced key features like the News Feed which became central to user engagement, and focused on generating revenue through targeted advertising based on user data, a model that drove its rapid financial growth.

## Acquisitions

In 2012, it purchased Instagram, followed by WhatsApp and Oculus VR in 2014, extending its influence beyond social networking into messaging and virtual reality.

## User Base

The highest number of Facebook users as of April 2023 are from India and the United States, followed by Indonesia, Brazil, Mexico and the Philippines.

## Controversies

Facebook has experienced a steady stream of controversies over how it handles user privacy, repeatedly adjusting its privacy settings and policies.

Facebook was created in 2004 by Mark Zuckerberg with four other Harvard College students and roommates, Eduardo Saverin, Andrew McCollum, Dustin Moskovitz, and Chris Hughes.(no content)It was launched as TheFacebook in 2004 and renamed Facebook in 2005, initially limited to Harvard students before expanding to other colleges and eventually to everyone with a valid email address by 2006.

## Growth and Dominance

Facebook had surpassed MySpace in global traffic and became the world's most popular social media platform.(no content)Facebook introduced key features like the News Feed which became central to user engagement, and focused on generating revenue through targeted advertising based on user data, a model that drove its rapid financial growth.

## Acquisitions

In 2012, it purchased Instagram, followed by WhatsApp and Oculus VR in 2014, extending its influence beyond social networking into messaging and virtual reality.

## User Base

The highest number of Facebook users as of April 2023 are from India and the United States, followed by Indonesia, Brazil, Mexico and the Philippines.

## Controversies

Facebook has experienced a steady stream of controversies over how it handles user privacy, repeatedly adjusting its privacy settings and policies.

Web search results for query: "Communication science"

Links: [{"title":"Communication studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_studies"},{"title":"Science communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_communication"},{"title":"Science Communication Observatory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_Communication_Observatory"},{"title":"Science Communication (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_Communication_(journal)"},{"title":"Science Communication Prize - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_Communication_Prize"},{"title":"List of science communication awards - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_science_communication_awards"},{"title":"Category:Science communication awards - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Science_communication_awards"},{"title":"History of communication studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_communication_studies"},{"title":"Climate communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_communication"},{"title":"Rutgers School of Communication and Information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rutgers_School_of_Communication_and_Information"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Communication Science:

## Definition and Scope

Communication studies (or communication science) is an academic discipline that deals with processes of human communication and behavior, patterns of communication in interpersonal relationships, social interactions and communication in different cultures.(no content)Communication studies is a social science that uses various methods of empirical investigation and critical analysis to develop a body of knowledge that encompasses a range of topics, from face-to-face conversation at a level of individual agency and interaction to social and cultural communication systems at a macro level.

## History

Prior to being established as its own discipline, communication studies was formed from three other major studies: psychology, sociology, and political science.(no content)The social science study was fully recognized as a legitimate discipline after World War II.(no content)The institutionalization of communication studies in U.S. higher education and research has often been traced to Columbia University, the University of Chicago, and the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, where early pioneers of the field worked after the Second World War.

## Modern Specializations

Today, this accepted discipline now also encompasses more modern forms of communication studies as well, such as gender and communication, intercultural communication, political communication, health communication, and organizational communication.

## Practical Applications

Communication studies is often perceived by many in society as being primarily centered around the media arts, however, those that become communication studies graduates could move on to have careers in areas ranging from media arts to public advocacy to marketing to non-profit organizations and even more.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Homophily social networks"

Links: [{"title":"Network homophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_homophily"},{"title":"Homophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homophily"},{"title":"Heterophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heterophily"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Homosocialization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homosocialization"},{"title":"List of LGBTQ social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_LGBT_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Homosociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homosociality"},{"title":"Fields of LGBTQ communication studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fields_of_LGBTQ_communication_studies"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Heterosociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heterosociality"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about homophily in social networks:

## Definition and Core Concept

Homophily is a concept in sociology describing the tendency of individuals to associate and bond with similar others, as in the proverb "birds of a feather flock together". In network terms, network homophily refers to the theory in network science which states that, based on node attributes, similar nodes may be more likely to attach to each other than dissimilar ones.

## Prevalence and Characteristics

Over 100 studies have observed homophily in some form or another, and they establish that similarity is associated with connection.(no content)Similarity can be defined by gender, race, age, occupation, educational achievement, status, values or any other salient characteristic.

## Dimensions of Homophily

The categories on which homophily occurs include age, gender, class, and organizational role. Additionally, value homophily involves association with others who have similar values, attitudes, and beliefs, regardless of differences in status characteristics.

## Network Effects

Homophily in social relations may lead to a commensurate distance in networks leading to the creation of clusters that have been observed in social networking services. Furthermore, homophily is a key topic in network science as it can determine the speed of the diffusion of information and ideas.

## Implications for Social Media

This homophily can foster divides and echo chambers on social networking sites, where people of similar ideologies only interact with each other.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Political discourse"

Links: [{"title":"Discourse analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discourse_analysis"},{"title":"Political discourse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Political_discourse&redirect=no"},{"title":"Talk:Political discourse analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Political_discourse_analysis"},{"title":"Rhetoric - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetoric"},{"title":"Populism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populism"},{"title":"Overton window - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overton_window"},{"title":"Paul Chilton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Chilton"},{"title":"Discourse on Voluntary Servitude - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discourse_on_Voluntary_Servitude"},{"title":"Public sphere - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_sphere"},{"title":"John Dryzek - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Dryzek"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of political discourse:

## Definition

Political discourse is the text and talk of professional politicians or political institutions, such as presidents and prime ministers and other members of government, parliament or political parties, both at the local, national and international levels, includes both the speaker and the audience. More broadly, political discourse is the formal exchange of reasoned views as to which of several alternative courses of action should be taken to solve a societal problem.

## Academic Study

Political discourse analysis is a field of discourse analysis which focuses on discourse in political forums (such as debates, speeches, and hearings) as the phenomenon of interest.(no content)Political discourse remains the paradigmatic example for studying and theorizing specific techniques and conceptions of persuasion or rhetoric.

## Public Sphere and Debate

Political discourse occurs within the broader context of the public sphere. The public sphere is an area in social life where individuals can come together to freely discuss and identify societal problems, and through that discussion, influence political action.(no content)Public debate takes place mostly through the mass media, but also at meetings or through social media, academic publications, and government policy documents.

## Boundaries of Political Discourse

An important concept related to political discourse is the Overton window. The Overton window is the range of subjects and arguments politically acceptable to the mainstream population at a given time. It is also known as the window of discourse.

## Public Sphere and Debate

Political discourse occurs within the broader context of the public sphere. The public sphere is an area in social life where individuals can come together to freely discuss and identify societal problems, and through that discussion, influence political action.(no content)Public debate takes place mostly through the mass media, but also at meetings or through social media, academic publications, and government policy documents.

## Boundaries of Political Discourse

An important concept related to political discourse is the Overton window. The Overton window is the range of subjects and arguments politically acceptable to the mainstream population at a given time. It is also known as the window of discourse.

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service and one of the world's largest social media platforms. Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts.

## History and Ownership

Twitter was created by Jack Dorsey, Noah Glass, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams in March 2006 and was launched that July. The company went public in November 2013. The service is now owned by the American company X Corp., which was established to succeed the prior owner Twitter, Inc. in March 2023 following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.

## Rebranding to X

In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024. Now operating as X, the platform closely resembles its predecessor but includes additional features such as long-form texts, account monetization options, audio-video calls, integration with xAI's Grok chatbot, job search, and a repurposing of the platform's verification system as a subscription premium.

## Recent Developments

In March 2025, X Corp. was acquired by xAI, Musk's artificial intelligence company, in an all-stock transaction that valued X at $33 billion, with a full valuation of $45 billion when factoring in $12 billion in debt.

Web search results for query: "Political polarization"

Links: [{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"File:The IRA, Social Media and Political Polarization in the United States, 2012-2018.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_IRA,_Social_Media_and_Political_Polarization_in_the_United_States,_2012-2018.pdf"},{"title":"Political polarization in Turkey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_Turkey"},{"title":"Negative partisanship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_partisanship"},{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"August 2023 Ohio Issue 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_2023_Ohio_Issue_1"},{"title":"2025 North Macedonian local elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_North_Macedonian_local_elections"},{"title":"Ground News - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_News"},{"title":"Millennial politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennial_politics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about political polarization:

## Definition

Political polarization is the divergence of political attitudes away from the center, towards ideological extremes.(no content)Polarization can be defined as "a prominent division or conflict that forms between major groups in a society or political system and that is marked by the clustering and radicalisation of views and beliefs at two distant and antagonistic poles."

## Types of Polarization

Scholars distinguish between different forms of polarization:

- Ideological polarization refers to differences between policy positions, while affective polarization refers to an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups.
- Political scientists distinguish between two levels: "elite polarization" which focuses on the polarization of political elites like party organizers and elected officials, and "mass polarization" which focuses on the polarization of the electorate or general public.

## Characteristics in Two-Party Systems

In a two-party system, a polarized legislature has little-to-no ideological overlap between the two parties, and almost all conflict over legislation is split across a broad ideological divide, leading to a conflation of political parties and ideologies and the collapse of an ideological center.

## Polarization in the United States

Polarization in the United States has increased since the 1970s, with rapid increases during the 2000s onwards, and members of both parties with unfavorable opinions of the opposing party have doubled since 1994, while those with very unfavorable opinions are at record highs as of 2022.

## Related Phenomena

Negative partisanship is the tendency of some voters to form their political opinions primarily in opposition to political parties they dislike, whereas traditional partisanship involves supporting the policy positions of one's own party.

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** `contribution`

**Triples Extracted:** 11 total

- **Tools** (4): Social media, Twitter, Facebook, WhatsApp
- **Methods** (1): Communication studies

- **Proposes** (3): The paper introduces three novel polarization measurement frameworks

- Every paper has at least 1 "uses" relation (8 total)
- The contribution paper has at least 1 "proposes" relation (3 total)
